raw.rawBlocker: We can't close enterprise deals. We've had 15 demos over the past 2 months but zero conversions. Prospects say they love the product, but the deal stalls after security review or just goes dark. We're burning runway and I don't know if the problem is the product, the pitch, or the process.
raw.rawAttempts: We've tried: (1) Following up more aggressively - didn't help, felt desperate. (2) Offering discounts - they weren't price sensitive, that wasn't the issue. (3) Bringing in a 'sales advisor' for 2 weeks - gave generic advice that didn't move the needle. (4) Creating more case study content - but we don't have real case studies yet.
raw.rawSuccessCriteria: Close our first enterprise customer (ARR > $50k). Even one deal would validate our sales motion and give us a reference customer.

problemArchetype.subPattern: first enterprise sale with no track record in B2B SaaS
problemArchetype.shapeDescription: Attempting to close enterprise deals without established credibility, case studies, or a proven sales process. Classic cold-start problem where prospects like the product but can't justify the risk of being first.

structured.problemStatement: Cannot convert interested enterprise prospects into paying customers due to lack of credibility and unclear buying process.

constraints.description: Burning runway with no revenue; need to close within 1-2 months
No prior enterprise sales experience on the team
Prospects may be comparing to established vendors

attemptedSolutions.whyItFailed: Came across as desperate; didn't address their underlying concerns
Price wasn't the blocker; it was trust/risk

attemptedSolutions.outcome: Generic playbook that didn't fit their situation
attemptedSolutions.whyItFailed: Advisor had B2C and SMB experience, not enterprise B2B

successCriteria.description: Close first enterprise customer with ARR > $50k

raw.rawProblem: We needed to close our first 3 enterprise customers for a compliance SaaS product, but we had no brand, no case studies, and prospects kept ghosting after the demo. Security and procurement teams were black boxes.
raw.rawContext: Series Seed, team of 4. We'd raised $1.5M but had 8 months of runway left. I was the CEO doing all the sales myself. We'd done about 20 demos with 0 conversions. Tried cold email sequences, tried LinkedIn outreach, tried content marketing - none of it was moving deals forward. The product was solid but nobody wanted to be first.
raw.rawSolution: I completely changed our approach. Instead of pitching our product, I started pitching a 'design partnership' - 3 months free in exchange for their input on the roadmap and a case study. I also stopped selling to the end-user and started mapping the buying committee first. Found the internal champion, then asked THEM who else needed to approve. Let them sell internally while I armed them with materials. The key was reducing their risk to near-zero while making them look good internally.
raw.rawOutcomes: Closed 3 enterprise customers in 4 months (all $40-80k ARR). One became our biggest reference customer. The design partnership model became our standard playbook for the next 2 years until we had enough credibility to sell normally. Raised Series A 6 months later partially on the strength of those logos.

problemArchetype.subPattern: first enterprise sale with no track record in B2B SaaS
problemArchetype.shapeDescription: Cold-start enterprise sales where prospects liked the product but couldn't justify being first. Required overcoming credibility gap and navigating complex buying committees without a playbook.

structured.problemStatement: Needed to close first enterprise customers for a compliance SaaS product with no brand recognition or case studies.

failedApproaches.description: Cold email sequences with product-focused messaging
failedApproaches.whyItFailed: High-volume, low-context outreach didn't build trust needed for enterprise deals
failedApproaches.lessonLearned: Enterprise sales is about trust-building, not volume

failedApproaches.whyItFailed: End-users couldn't make buying decisions; needed executive sponsorship
failedApproaches.lessonLearned: Map the buying committee before starting any sales motion

failedApproaches.whyItFailed: Takes 6-12 months to generate meaningful inbound; didn't have time
failedApproaches.lessonLearned: Content is long-term; need different strategy for first customers

successfulApproach.description: Design partnership model: 3 months free in exchange for input + case study. Mapped buying committee first, armed internal champion with materials.
keyActions: Reframed pitch from 'buy our product' to 'partner with us to shape the product'
Asked prospects to introduce their internal stakeholders (security, procurement, legal)
Created internal selling materials for champions to use
Reduced risk to near-zero with free trial + executive sponsorship
successfulApproach.whyItWorked: Eliminated the risk of being first by making it a partnership. Made the champion look good internally by positioning them as innovative.

insights.insight: First enterprise customers require a fundamentally different motion than scaling sales. Reduce their risk to near-zero.
insights.whenApplicable: Pre-revenue or early-revenue B2B SaaS selling to enterprise
insights.whenNotApplicable: Once you have 5+ reference customers and case studies

insights.insight: Never sell to just the end-user. Map the buying committee early and arm your champion with internal selling materials.
insights.whenApplicable: Any enterprise deal with multiple stakeholders

exampleMatch.explanation: This mentor navigated the exact challenge you're facing: closing first enterprise deals in B2B SaaS with no brand recognition or case studies. They went from 0 to 3 enterprise customers in 4 months using a 'design partnership' model that reduces prospect risk to near-zero. Their experience with compliance SaaS means they understand the security review and procurement dynamics you're hitting. Most importantly, they failed at the same things you've tried (aggressive follow-up, discounts, generic advisors) before finding what worked.

componentReasoning.problemShapeSimilarity: Both are 'first enterprise sale with no track record' problems in B2B SaaS. Same archetype category, same sub-pattern. The mentor solved exactly this problem.
componentReasoning.constraintAlignment: Strong alignment on runway pressure and solo founder sales. Mentor had slightly more runway (8 vs 4 months) but similar urgency. No conflicting constraints.
componentReasoning.stageRelevance: Mentor's experience at Seed stage is directly applicable to pre-seed. Adjacent stages with similar dynamics.
componentReasoning.experienceDepth: Deep experience demonstrated by multiple failed approaches documented with lessons learned, specific tactical actions, and measurable outcomes.
componentReasoning.recency: 2021 experience is recent enough to be relevant. Enterprise sales fundamentals haven't changed significantly.

keyAlignments: Identical problem archetype: first enterprise sale in B2B SaaS with no credibility
Failed approaches overlap: both tried aggressive follow-up and generic advisors
Constraint match: founder-led sales with runway pressure
concerns: Mentor's experience was in compliance SaaS; may have industry-specific dynamics
Founder has 4 months runway vs mentor's 8; may need faster path to close
